Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2009 09:40AM LJ13-2 wrote: Her risk of colon cancer is higher than the normal population. Also ovarian cancer. Her risk of a new primary breast cancer is 20-40% lifetime. Best not to think of the numbers; get the recommended screenings, be aware of one's body, get examined if something doesn't go away in 2-3 weeks, and just try to enjoy life. Statistics suck.

Posts.Title: Help...Doc recommends elective mastectomy... Mandi322 Georganne

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2009 12:44PM LJ13-2 wrote: It's pretty standard procedure to put the clip in at the site of a biopsy. It's not because they "think" it's a tumor. It's so that they can be sure to find the tumor bed if surgery is needed. Some docs still like the personal approach. Many just do a phone call. Don't try to "interpret" results from the signs. You'll have answers soon enough. I know that waiting is hard. Try to stay busy with things other than breast cancer.

Posts.Title: HAIR AFTER CHEMO Deborah51 Sugar77

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2010 05:16PM - edited Jun 7, 2010 05:18PM by LJ13-2 So, in words that are less jargon-y, the thing is a dried up, unused lymph vessel. When they removed the nodes, there was nothing left for that vessel to drain into. Now your body has to forge new vessels to drain the arm, axilla, and all the other areas that used to be serviced by those nodes and that dried up vessel. 2 things have helped me. Each night, for months after the node removal, lying in bed I would elevate the affected arm, as if reaching to touch the ceiling. Squeeze your fist about 20 times. Count to 5 for each squeeze, and count to 5 again as you open your fist. Repeat 20 times. Then, use the good hand to rub the arm (held in the same position), from hand to shoulder, as if you are pushing fluid from your hand all the way up your arm to the shoulder. Use firm pressure, but don't squeeze hard. Do that 20-40 times. I would work the inside and outside of the arm separately, alternating. Both of these exercises help your arm develop new drainage routes for lymph fluid.

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2009 06:35PM LJ13-2 wrote: Stage is a statistical method of classifying your odds of living past 5 years. It can sometimes help guide treatment, but of itself does nothing to 'cure' a cancer. If they do neoadjuvant chemo (before surgery), you never know your stage for sure. Many women, especially in the US and particularly at large hospitals where the latest treatment modalities are used, get chemo before surgery. Don't focus on stage. Focus on the pathology and the recommended treatments.
Posts.Title: Mom just diagnosed cgrove0518 nash

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2010 10:38AM LJ13-2 wrote: LindaLou, I can point you to (or you can do the searching yourself) studies about reading "tone" into posts. Personally, I simply get tired of slogging through posts here where people toss around jargon that is less than helpful to the poster. It doesn't matter if lymph vessels are thrombosed or dried up ... they aren't being used, they are causing pain, what to do about it? Interesting that you want a study about massage generating growth of lymph vessels. Sorry, I don't know of any. I read that the process may help regrowth. It was on a reputable site about lymphedema. It was logical. I believed it. If you choose not to believe it, that's fine too. I'm pretty sure that gently massaging the arm isn't going to prevent vessel regrowth ... in general stimulation does inspire growth in the body. How would they even DO a study of this?
Posts.Title: rope like tendon? becky1 jeanwash

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2010 04:43PM LJ13-2 wrote: Part of the 5-year issue is that the AIs and Tamox are typically taken for 5 years which suppresses tumor growth/recurrence. Once these drugs are removed, there is a spike, statistically, in recurrence rates.
Posts.Title: Stage 1 and Mets mari65 barbe1958

Posts.Content: May 18, 2010 04:34PM LJ13-2 wrote: My Rad Onc said "because of your age, we wanted to treat you fully." My age being 50 at the time. Treating me fully meant that the field would comprise breast, supraclav nodes, and axilla (positive nodes). Rads does increase the chances of lymphedema. Lung cancer for smokers and former smokers. Even possible new primary bc. However, I was determined to fight the cancer I had, not some possible future problem. I did not want to have to deal with the regret of a path not chosen. If I were to recur, it would be only after fighting the bc with every tool I had.

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2009 09:43AM LJ13-2 wrote: I drank some in my late teens (it was legal for b+w then), a good bit in my 20s, less in my 30s. When I stopped playing softball in my mid-late 30s, I pretty much stopped drinking. By then I was only drinking after games, the pitchers of beer at the bar thing. Since then (15+ years), I've had a few sips of champagne or brandy, literally just a few sips. I just didn't enjoy the taste or feeling any more. Didn't help a bit to prevent bc, but that was never the point of not drinking. It doesn't bother me to be the sole non-drinker in a group. I just have my water.
